thread.title: Dollar Bulls Accelerate Charge as Yellen Provides Rates Spur
thread.title_full: Dollar Bulls Accelerate Charge as Yellen Provides Rates Spur - Bloomberg Business

author: Kevin Buckland
title: Dollar Bulls Accelerate Charge as Yellen Provides Rates Spur
text:
The dollar headed for its longest stretch of weekly gains since March after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen reiterated the U.S. is on track to raise interest rates this year.
The U.S. currency was set for its biggest weekly gain in almost two months versus the euro after the Greek parliament voted to accept further austerity required for a new bailout, clearing one obstacle to higher U.S. borrowing costs. The New Zealand dollar plunged to a six-year low after whole milk powder prices slumped at an auction. The Aussie remained lower with its Canadian peer after the Bank of Canada cut rates.
“The Fed is still on the way to hiking this year,” said Tomohisa Fujiki, the head of interest-rate strategy for Japan at BNP Paribas SA in Tokyo. “The dollar should strengthen.”
The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index, which tracks the U.S. currency against 10 of its major peers, was at 1,202.17 as of 9:17 a.m. in Tokyo, after closing at 1,200.76 on Wednesday, the highest since April 13. It has risen 1.1 percent this week.
The greenback traded at $1.0933 per euro from $1.0950 in New York. It added 0.1 percent to 123.89 yen.
The U.S. currency may gain to $1.02 per euro and to 130 yen by Dec. 31, Fujiki said.
“If the economy evolves as we expect, economic conditions likely would make it appropriate at some point this year to raise the federal funds rate target,” Yellen said in testimony Wednesday before the House Financial Services Committee in Washington. She said Fed officials expect growth to strengthen this year and the unemployment rate to decline gradually.
Greek Bailout Greek lawmakers passed a bailout agreement that keeps the country in the euro in a midnight vote in Athens. The result puts the onus on the European Central Bank and other euro-region governments to put in place more emergency funds that will help Greek banks gradually re-open and repair the country’s battered coffers.
Yellen had said in June there could be spillover to the U.S. if there were no agreement between Greece and its creditors.
Fed funds futures show a 67 percent chance the central bank will increase its benchmark rate by year-end from virtually zero, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. The central bank last raised the rate in 2006.
The New Zealand dollar plunged after whole milk powder prices plunged 13.1 percent in the GlobalDairyTrade auction overnight, spurring speculation that the central bank has added reason to cut interest rates again.
Kiwi Slides Reserve Bank Governor Graeme Wheeler has said that weaker prospects for dairy prices will curb farm incomes and delay inflation returning to his 2 percent target.
The kiwi declined 0.5 percent 65.60 U.S. cents after falling as low as to 65.58, the weakest since July 2009.
The greenback surged to a six-year high against the Canadian dollar Wednesday after the Bank of Canada cut its benchmark interest rate for a second time this year, and spurred speculation it could augur further stimulus in other commodity-producing nations.
The loonie traded at C$1.2920 per U.S. dollar after sliding 1.4 percent to C$1.2913 Wednesday. The Aussie declined 0.2 percent to 73.68 U.S. cents after dropping 1 percent in New York.
